>>10173255
>The characters are mostly misses now since they're just disney+ shit, but the characters being new sculpts is a fact.
How new are you?
The shit Hasbro does now is FAR LESS than how it used to be.

Hasbro produces brand new molds for movie/tv series because they're contractually obligated to. This is how it's been since they got the Marvel license in the late 00s and how it's been for Star Wars since at least the prequels.
However, they rolled their movie lines into the generic Marvel Legends/TBS/vintage/etc lines to save money/get more orders. Before, the movie lines had standalone toylines and there were 2-5 waves for every movie. That's 3-6 figures every single wave. So lines like IM2 had a shit ton (30+) of brand new molded figures. Today, at best you'll get 6 figures + maybe a BAF for the movies, AND it replaces a normal wave. Whereas before the ML/MU line was still being released concurrently with the movie lines.

So it really doesn't even compare to what McFarlane is doing, because McFarlane makes brand new molds for 98% of the non-movie figures. Shit doesn't even begin to compare with McFarlane or even how old HAsbro used to do it. And we complained about Hasbro's reuse even back then.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
KongAnon here, I finally have something new to report. I got my crepe hair and CA glue and I'm practicing fur layering on a piece of scrap from the Playmates 11" King Kong. I tried a couple different glues and I can say srtraight up, loctite is a bad choice for this kind of work because it turns a chalky white color if you use accelerant on it. Thin CA glue is also a bad choice because it's too runny and makes a mess. The two glue types I find that work well are Gorilla brand superglue, and what I think is going to be my primary glue for the project, Bob Smith Industries Insta-Cure. It goes on clear enough with accelerant, and it's possible to air cure it with a little patience in areas that need it.

One of the things I discovered early on is that the crepe hair needs to go on long and get trimmed afterward. The crepe hair comes in a braid, and to make it straight I had to use a flat iron, although I hear a regular clothing iron will work too. The fur also needs to get brushed after a while to get rid of any loose hairs and to make sure everything is running in the right direction.

I'd take pics of the process but it's kind of a pain to photograph it. Maybe I will make an attempt to make some kind of tutorial once I have the hang of it though, if people are interested.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Hey /toy/,
New collector here, so far I've put together a small cabinet of McFarlane DC, Marvel Legends and NECA Horror figures, with a few other series dotted about (I'm a sucker for anything Toxic Crusaders), but when looking at other lines to start, I need some advice.

I usually start off with the 'main' characters (founding Avengers, The Trinity etc) but with other lines like Retro Star Wars, G.I. Joe, especially Transformers and Power Rangers Lightning Collection and some others I've looked at, this seems to be increasingly difficult to source. Once a Wave is released and sold out, am I stuck to scouring eBay and the like? Or are Waves sometimes re-released?

I'm in the U.K. which makes it a bit harder, but even when sucking it up and looking at doing a big BBTS order, there's some stuff I just can't mind (Lightning MMPR Blue, for example)
Struggling to decide which lines to persue so that I'm not stuck with grabbing JUST C-List characters (as much as I do love ML Maggot).

Thanks for any advice

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10171699
Go on Facebook and join various local/UK toy groups. See if there's any dedicated to selling/buying the line of your choice. And go from there. In time, you may notice some regular trusted sellers.

Also go with Amazon and the like. I assume there's an Amazon UK?

As for what lines, it really depends on what you like. I presume you're a 6" to 7" collector. The lines you've mentioned are pretty much the best non-Eastern on the market for that kind of stuff.

GI Joe are probably the most advance engineering-wise and bang for your buck-wise (unless they're ludicrously overpriced in the UK?).

threads.com:
Welcome back everyone, hope you're all doing well.

The time has come for us to finally have new releases in the line! By now most of everyone who ordered Olivier and Vania should have them in hand. As of now, we only have one other figure up for Pre-Order right now, that being Bikini Clover. We also had a wonderful surprise in the form of the new Polynian MLL body! We finally have a counterpart to the Iana body. Aside from that things have been pretty quiet for the time being.

As always, here is the assistance e-mail for those who need it, so if any problem should arise, feel free to contact them over at "user_support@mile-stone.jp" or the shop you purchased the figure from.

Once again, feel free to share your photos and adventures, they add life and some fun to the thread. Also, welcome newcomers, we hope you enjoy your stay.

because being plastic is a chemical process. Chemicals leak, break down, mix with other things, while being "solid". It why certain plastics yellow in the sun, its why certain plastics become brittle. Most toys are still just toys, and arent considered by companies for long terms effects.

Other effects happen because companies take precautions. Things like the NES and SNES can extremely yellow, and thats from the type of fire retardant chemicals they used in the plastic that unfortunately are effected by uv rays.

figures holding guns is one of the hardest things there is.
You can fake it most of the time, but to give them all the range needed to properly shoulder them? Either you make the guns undersized and remove part of teh sculpt, or you have some ugly disjointed toy like an Amazing Yamaguchi that costs $50+.

You can also cut out a ton of sculpt from the standard figure, but that doesn't always help.

PS, MGR used to make less accurate guns to make them more compatible, but sales prove that people want more accurate guns.
